content.description: And the sit goes! Start low in the cave using the block horn under the roof for your left and your right on the incut spot on the rail.  The next moves are powerful slaps out to the lip using heels and toes to get to the start of Tsunami stand.  Climb to the top.
content.protection: 6 pad minimum. More are ideal. There are many different ways you can fall off of this thing, and some of them would lead to serious injury.  You want a spotter.
content.location: Located in the closely clumped tier 3, the tsunami boulder is perched up the hill on a prominent talus field.

content.description: This problem starts with a left hand on the lowest undercling, a right on the closest rail on the right arêt, and super challenging feet. I started low on the rail, but I think it makes more sense to start high. I've circled my original start hold, and a suggested start hold and posted it in the photos. From there, make a very powerful right hand move to a good sloper knob, then work your way to the jug on the top of the face through a series of underclings and crimps. From there, I exit right by climbing Gettin' Bodied (v4-5). There is an alternate exit that climbs left and tops out on the face, but it's an extremely committing sloper mantle and I decided against it.The opening move is the crux, and felt on the upper end of v8 for me on it's own. That said, the alternate suggested starting hold may make that a bit easier. All in all, it may be harder than 8 but I want to get some feedback from others first as I've spent too many sessions on it to judge at this point.
content.location: On the third tier right near the cliff. If you walk up from the tier two boulders and traverse left you'll come to it in 150 feet.

content.description: Fantastic looking boulder that climbs just as well.  Start matched low on an uncut jug on the lip under the wave.  Climb up right and figure out how to get over the bulge and ride the wave  to the top!  A spotter would be handy for the top out due to the tiered landing.Looks like a full sit starting low under the cave would go, adding around 5+ moves into the stand and would be incredibly awesome
content.protection: 3-4 pads required to protect the talus below
content.location: Located in the closely clumped tier 3, the tsunami boulder is perched up the hill on a prominent talus field.

content.description: Sit start with your feet low under the boulder using a left hand pinch and a right hand side pull. Set your heel and fire up to a crimp on the right of the arete. Use good side pulls to work up and left to the lip to top out.
content.location: This boulder sits to the right of the squeeze pass entrance to tier 3 cluster as you are coming up the hill from tier 2.

content.description: Start on the far right of the gentle scoop/curve. There's an obvious side-pull rail, and a big foot. Walk your feet left (the crux), which can involve a cool palm press for balance, and then ride the arêt until you pull over the lip at the top.
content.protection: 3 pads or a spotter to move one.
content.location: Find the mini cliff band with Bepop and Rocksteady. Turn around (180º) and you should see this boulder behind you about 75 feet away.

content.description: Start the same as Bebob, then traverse right using flakes and edges, to jugs. Slightly harder, but more interesting climbing.

Short powerful problem. Sit start on tiny crimps. If you can’t reach the holds from the ground, pad it up. The pull from the sit is hard and fun. Make a hard pull and a big move to a right hand sloper. Keep tension and move left to a decent side pull. Bump right to a good hold and go straight up. Short and sweet. It’s best to down climb a little then jump off to get down.
content.protection: Two pads. It’s not that tall, but the landing slopes away a little. I brought the second pad to level out the landing.
content.location: Boulder directly right of Bebop and Rocksteady.

content.description: Sit start for entrance exam.  Start matched on the incut edge at the end of the sloping rail. Pop up into a gaston on the starting hold of entrance exam. Set the heel and match.  Now climb entrance exam to the lip.
content.protection: Flat landing that takes 1-2 pads to protect.
content.location: This boulder sits to the right of the squeeze pass entrance to tier 3 cluster as you are coming up the hill from tier 2.

content.description: Sit start low in the shallow groove matched on a sloper. Move straight up to a cool hold basically at the lip of the boulder. It is possible to mantel here, it’s heinous, and don’t you want to make more moves? To continue climbing, swap into a pinch with the left hand, and move right using a couple sidepulls. Move your body right and go up to the lip. Match, put your foot on the cool block feature and press it out.
content.location: This is located below the initial cluster you reach when getting to tier three. Head down hill, you will see it on the right. There is a small pine tree right where you put your pads. I didn’t have the heart to cut it. Lol

content.description: Slightly overhung vertical face with solid crimping all the way to the top.
content.protection: 3-4 pads due to the uneven landing.
content.location: Located in the tier 3 cluster directly across from the squeeze way entrance into the amphitheater.

content.description: Sit start on a low rail with a pinch and a sloper, bad feet. Make a move up to good holds then top out on jugs. Really fun!
Stand starting matched on an undercling jug.  Throw to the right Gaston and use the left side pull to build feet and throw to the lip of the boulder to top out.
content.protection: Flat landing that takes 1-2 pads to protect.
content.location: This boulder sits to the right of the squeeze pass entrance to tier 3 cluster as you are coming up the hill from tier 2.

content.description: Stand start matched on the diamond feature at head height. Pull on and traverse left into extra credit. Finish straight up.

Coffee Cake is the most calorically dense baked good available at Old Village Bakery... Oh wait this is the rock climb. Coffee Cake is 

the most calorically dense sloper traverse   a dense sloper traverse running across the first lip of Changing Corners. Start sitting just left of the corner with your hands on the lip, pull on and go left until you hit jugs on the other side of the arete. Wait for a cold day for this one, otherwise the Coffee Cake will feel extra buttery.
content.location: In the fingers for breakfast alcove, coffee cake is the sloping arete that starts next to changing corners

content.description: Start down low in the talus hole and start matched on the arete.  With high feet, work up to the sloping block feature and figure out how to change directions and finish by climbing up the opposite facing rail above to top out.  This is a fantastic climb with great movement and makes you think.
content.protection: 4-5 pads may be required to adequately protect the low start and uneven surfaces.
content.location: Located to the left once you enter the amphitheater.  Find the two tiered boulder and the start is down low in the talus hole.

content.description: Sit start matched on the left side of the long low edge. Feet are terrible. Make a big hard move straight up. Finish straight up on crimps.
content.location: When you get to tier three head downhill a bit, walking by the entirety of the big cluster. Once on the other side head straight up keeping the cluster to your right. This is more of a small wall than a boulder.

content.description:
Up the hill from Tier 2 is another amazing cluster of boulders that we named Tier 3.   

  You will know you have reached the Tier 3 cluster when you find yourself in a boulder squeeze pass that you have to take your pads off to get through.  Trust me, its worth it!  Once you've squeezed through, you will enter into an amphitheater of very large boulders and have arrived. The landings for these boulder problems are more uneven and require more pads. 

  Changing corners is a fantastic V5 that will make you think. The potential for more boulders is endless and this area will benefit from more traffic!  There are more boulders up the hill as well as down left. A simple walk and you will find many more routes waiting to be climbed.  

  Routes are re-discovered every day and it is advised to bring a wire brush to scrub some lichen if you see a line that is inspiring!  We have reached out to local climbers about potential FA's in the past but currently have little information. Route names are temporary and please leave a comment if you have knowledge about existing names and first ascentionists. The bouldering potential here is endless and more people should come out and climb on these fantastic blocks!
